Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of PRP and Autologous Blood Injections for Lateral Epicondylitis

Participants.evidence: adults with clinically diagnosed lateral epicondylitis unresponsive to nonoperative treatment. Exclusion criteria included other upper-limb symptoms and prior elbow surgery.

Intervention.evidence: to receive PRP, autologous blood, or saline injections

Objective.evidence: assessed the effectiveness of platelet-rich plasma (PRP) and autologous blood injections versus saline in treating lateral epicondylitis

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pain improvement on the VAS scale at 52 weeks.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomised (1:1:1) using computer-generated sequences, concealed from investigators

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 119 participants were randomised: 40 to PRP, 40 to autologous blood, and 39 to saline.

Number_Analysed.evidence: At 52 weeks, 31 PRP, 38 autologous blood, and 32 saline participants were analysed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean VAS pain difference was -0.2 (95% CI -1.5 to 1.1; p = 0.75) for PRP vs. saline and 0.5 (95% CI -0.7 to 1.7; p = 0.40) for autologous blood vs. saline.

Funding.evidence: Funded by the local hospital district.
